name: William Gilbert
motivation: hypothesized that the Earth is a giant magnet

name: Galileo Galilei
motivation: performed fundamental observations, experiments, and mathematical analyses in astronomy and physics; discovered mountains and craters on the moon, the phases of Venus, and the four largest satellites of Jupiter: Io, Europa, Callisto, and Ganymede

name: Willebrod Snell
motivation: discovered law of refraction (Snell's law)

name: Blaise Pascal
motivation: discovered that pressure applied to an enclosed fluid is transmitted undiminished to every part of the fluid and to the walls of its container (Pascal's principle)

name: Christiaan Huygens
motivation: proposed a simple geometrical wave theory of light, now known as ``Huygen's principle''; pioneered use of the pendulum in clocks

name: Robert Hooke
motivation: discovered Hooke's law of elasticity

name: Sir Isaac Newton
motivation: developed theories of gravitation and mechanics,  and invented differential calculus

name: Daniel Bernoulli
motivation: developed the fundamental relationship of fluid flow now known as Bernoulli's principle

name: Benjamin Franklin
motivation: the first American physicist; characterized two kinds of electric charge, which he named ``positive'' and ``negative''

name: Leonard Euler
motivation: made fundamental contributions to fluid dynamics, lunar orbit theory (tides), and mechanics; also contributed prolifically  to all areas of classical mathematics

name: Henry Cavendish
motivation: discovered and studied hydrogen; first to measure Newton's  gravitational constant; calculated mass and mean density of Earth

name: Charles Augustin de Coulomb
motivation: experiments on elasticity, electricity, and magnetism; established experimentally nature of the force between two charges

name: Joseph-Louis Lagrange
motivation: developed new methods of analytical mechanics

name: James Watt
motivation: invented the modern condensing steam engine and  a centrifugal governor

name: Count Alessandro Volta
motivation: pioneer in study of electricity; invented the first electric battery

name: Joseph Fourier
motivation: established the differential equation governing heat diffusion and solved it by devising an infinite series of sines and cosines capable of approximating a wide variety of functions

name: Thomas Young
motivation: studied light and color; known for his double-slit experiment that demonstrated the wave nature of light

name: Jean-Babtiste Biot
motivation: studied polarization of light; co-discovered that intensity of magnetic field set up by a current flowing through a wire varies inversely with the distance from the wire

name: Andr%26eacute; Marie Amp%26egrave;re
motivation: father of electrodynamics

name: Amadeo Avogadro
motivation: developed hypothesis that all gases at same volume, pressure, and temperature contain same number of atoms

name: Johann Carl Friedrich Gauss
motivation: formulated separate electrostatic and electrodynamical laws, including ``Gauss' law''; contributed to development of number theory,   differential geometry, potential theory, theory of terrestrial magnetism, and methods of calculating planetary orbits

name: Hans Christian Oersted
motivation: discovered that a current in a wire can produce magnetic effects

name: Sir David Brewster
motivation: deduced ``Brewster's law'' giving the angle of incidence that produces reflected light which is completely polarized; invented the kaleidoscope and the stereoscope, and improved the spectroscope

name: Augustin-Jean Fresnel
motivation: studied transverse nature of light waves

name: Georg Ohm
motivation: discovered that current flow is proportional to potential difference and inversely proportional to resistance  (Ohm's law)

name: Michael Faraday
motivation: discovered electromagnetic induction and devised first electrical transformer

name: Felix Savart
motivation: co-discovered that intensity of magnetic field set up by a current flowing through a wire varies inversely with the distance from the wire

name: Sadi Carnot
motivation: founded the science of thermodynamics

name: Joseph Henry
motivation: performed extensive fundamental studies of electromagnetic phenomena; devised first practical electric motor

name: Christian Doppler
motivation: experimented with sound waves; derived an expression for the apparent change in wavelength of a wave due to relative motion between the source and observer

name: Wilhelm E. Weber
motivation: developed sensitive magnetometers; worked in electrodynamics and the electrical structure of matter

name: Sir William Hamilton
motivation: developed the principle of least action and the Hamiltonian form of classical mechanics

name: James Prescott Joule
motivation: discovered mechanical equivalent of heat

name: Armand-Hippolyte-Louis Fizeau
motivation: made the first terrestrial measurement of the speed of light; invented one of the first interferometers; took the first pictures of the Sun on daguerreotypes; argued that the Doppler effect with respect to sound should also apply to any wave motion, particularly that of light

name: Jean-Bernard-L%26eacute;on Foucault
motivation: accurately measured speed of light; invented the gyroscope; demonstrated the Earth's rotation

name: Sir George Gabriel Stokes
motivation: described the motion of viscous fluids by independently discovering the Navier-Stokes equations of fluid mechanics (or hydrodynamics); developed Stokes theorem by which certain surface integrals may be reduced to line integrals; discovered fluorescence

name: Hermann von Helmholtz
motivation: developed first law of thermodynamics, a statement of conservation of energy

name: Rudolf Clausius
motivation: developed second law of thermodynamics, a statement that the entropy of the Universe always increases

name: Lord Kelvin
motivation: proposed absolute temperature scale, of essence to development of thermodynamics

name: Gustav Kirchhoff
motivation: developed three laws of spectral analysis  and three rules of electric circuit analysis; also contributed to optics

name: Johann Balmer
motivation: developed empirical formula to describe hydrogen spectrum

name: Sir Joseph Wilson Swan
motivation: developed a carbon-filament incandescent light; patented the carbon process for printing photographs in permanent pigment

name: James Clerk Maxwell
motivation: propounded the theory of electromagnetism; developed the kinetic theory of gases

name: Josef Stefan
motivation: studied blackbody radiation

name: Ernst Mach
motivation: studied conditions that occur when an object moves through a fluid at high speed (the ``Mach number'' gives the ratio of the speed of the object to the speed of sound in the fluid); proposed ``Mach's principle,'' which states that the inertia of an object is due to the interaction between the object and the rest of the universe

name: Josiah Gibbs
motivation: developed chemical thermodynamics; introduced concepts of free energy and chemical potential

name: James Dewar
motivation: liquified nitrogen and invented the Dewar flask,  which is critical for low-temperature work

name: Osborne Reynolds
motivation: contributed to the fields of hydraulics and hydrodynamics;  developed mathematical framework for  turbulence and introduced the ``Reynolds number,'' which provides a criterion for dynamic similarity and correct modeling in many fluid-flow experiments

name: Ludwig Boltzmann
motivation: developed statistical mechanics and applied it to kinetic theory of gases

name: Roland E%26ouml;tv%26ouml;s
motivation: demonstrated equivalence of gravitational and  inertial mass

name: Oliver Heaviside
motivation: contributed to the development of electromagnetism; introduced operational calculus and invented the modern notation for vector calculus; predicted existence of the Heaviside layer (a layer of the Earth's ionosphere)

name: George Francis FitzGerald
motivation: hypothesized foreshortening of moving bodies  (Lorentz-FitzGerald contraction) to explain the result of the Michelson-Morley experiment

name: John Henry Poynting
motivation: demonstrated that the energy flow of electromagnetic waves could be calculated by an equation (now called Poynting's vector)

name: Henri Poincar%26eacute;
motivation: founded qualitative dynamics (the mathematical theory of dynamical systems); created topology; contributed to solution of the three-body problem; first described many properties of deterministic chaos; contributed to the development of special relativity

name: Janne Rydberg
motivation: analyzed the spectra of many elements;  discovered many line series were described by a formula that depended on a  universal constant (the Rydberg constant)

name: Edwin H. Hall
motivation: discovered the ``Hall effect,'' which occurs when charge carriers moving through a material are deflected because of an applied magnetic field - the deflection results in a potential difference across the side of the material that is transverse to both the magnetic field and the current direction

name: Heinrich Hertz
motivation: worked on electromagnetic phenomena; discovered radio waves and the photoelectric effect

name: Nikola Tesla
motivation: created alternating current

name: Johannes van der Waals
motivation: worked on equations of state for gases and liquids

name: Lord Rayleigh
motivation: discovered argon; explained how light scattering is responsible for red color of sunset and blue color of sky

name: Wilhelm R%26ouml;ntgen
motivation: discovered and studied x rays

name: Antoine Henri Becquerel
motivation: discovered natural radioactivity

name: Albert A. Michelson
motivation: devised an interferometer and used it to try to measure Earth's absolute motion; precisely measured speed of light

name: Hendrik Antoon Lorentz
motivation: introduced Lorentz transformation equations of  special relativity; advanced ideas of relativistic length contraction and relativistic mass increase; contributed to theory of electromagnetism

name: Heike Kamerlingh-Onnes
motivation: liquified helium; discovered superconductivity

name: Sir Joseph John Thomson
motivation: demonstrated existence of the electron

name: Max Planck
motivation: formulated the quantum theory; explained wavelength distribution of blackbody radiation

name: Pierre Curie
motivation: studied radioactivity with wife, Marie Curie; discovered piezoelectricity

name: Sir William Henry Bragg
motivation: worked on x-ray spectrometry

name: Philipp von Lenard
motivation: studied cathode rays and the photoelectric effect

name: Wilhelm Wien
motivation: discovered laws governing radiation of heat

name: Pieter Zeeman
motivation: discovered splitting of spectral lines in a strong magnetic field

name: Marie Curie
motivation: discovered radioactivity of thorium; co-discovered radium and polonium

name: Robert Millikan
motivation: measured the charge of an electron; introduced term ``cosmic rays'' for the radiation coming from outer space; studied the photoelectric effect

name: Charles Wilson
motivation: invented the cloud chamber

name: Jean Baptiste Perrin
motivation: experimentally proved that cathode rays were streams  of negatively charged particles; experimentally confirmed the correctness of Einstein's theory of Brownian motion, and through his measurements obtained a new determination of Avogadro's number

name: Lord Ernest Rutherford
motivation: theorized existence of the atomic nucleus based on results of the alpha-scattering experiment performed by Hans Geiger and Ernest Marsden; developed theory of Rutherford scattering (scattering of spinless, pointlike particles from a Coulomb potential)

name: Guglielmo Marconi
motivation: invented the first practical system of wireless  telegraphy

name: Johannes Stark
motivation: discovered splitting of spectral lines in a strong electric field

name: Charles Glover Barkla
motivation: discovered that every chemical element, when irradiated by x rays, can emit an x-ray spectrum of two line-groups, which he named the K-series and L-series, that are of fundamental importance to understanding atomic structure

name: Albert Einstein
motivation: explained Brownian motion and photoelectric effect; contributed to theory of atomic spectra; formulated theories of  special and general relativity

name: Otto Hahn
motivation: discovered the fission of heavy nuclei

name: Max von Laue
motivation: discovered diffraction of x rays by crystals

name: Sir Owen Richardson
motivation: discovered the basic law of thermionic emission, now called the Richardson (or Richardson-Dushman) equation, which describes the emission of electrons from a heated conductor

name: Clinton Joseph Davisson
motivation: co-discovered electron diffraction

name: Max Born
motivation: contributed to creation of quantum mechanics; pioneer in the theory of crystals

name: Percy Williams Bridgman
motivation: invented an apparatus to produce extremely high pressures; made many discoveries in high-pressure physics

name: James Franck
motivation: experimentally confirmed that atomic energy states are quantized

name: Victor Franz Hess
motivation: discovered cosmic radiation

name: Peter Debye
motivation: used methods of statistical mechanics to calculate equilibrium properties of solids; contributed  to knowledge of molecular structure

name: Niels Bohr
motivation: contributed to quantum theory and to theory of nuclear reactions and nuclear fission

name: Karl Manne Georg Siegbahn
motivation: made important experimental contributions to the field of x-ray spectroscopy

name: Gustav Hertz
motivation: experimentally confirmed that atomic energy states are quantized

name: Erwin Schr%26ouml;dinger
motivation: contributed to creation of quantum mechanics; formulated the Schr%26ouml;dinger wave equation

name: Sir Chandrasekhara Raman
motivation: studied light scattering and discovered the Raman effect

name: Otto Stern
motivation: contributed to development of the molecular beam method; discovered the magnetic moment of the proton

name: Frits Zernike
motivation: invented the phase-contrast microscope, a type of  microscope widely used for examining specimens such as biological cells and tissues

name: Sir William Lawrence Bragg
motivation: worked on crystal structure and x rays

name: Walther Bothe
motivation: devised a coincidence counter for studying cosmic rays; demonstrated validity of energy-momentum conservation at the atomic scale

name: Sir James Chadwick
motivation: discovered the neutron

name: Sir Edward Appleton
motivation: discovered the layer of the Earth's atmosphere, called the Appleton layer, which is the part of the ionosphere having the highest concentration of free electrons and is the most useful for  radio transmission

name: Prince Louis-Victor de Broglie
motivation: predicted wave properties of the electron

name: Arthur Compton
motivation: discovered the increase in wavelength of x rays when scattered by an electron

name: Sir George Paget Thomson
motivation: co-discovered electron diffraction

name: Harold Clayton Urey
motivation: discovered deuterium

name: Pjotr Leonidovich Kapitsa
motivation: heralded a new era of low-temperature physics by inventing a device for producing liquid helium without previous cooling with liquid hydrogen; demonstrated that Helium II is a quantum superfluid

name: Igor Y. Tamm
motivation: co-developed the theoretical interpretation of the radiation of electrons moving through matter faster than the speed of light (the ``Cerenkov effect''), and developed the theory of showers in cosmic rays

name: Robert S. Mulliken
motivation: introduced the theoretical concept of the molecular orbital, which led to a new understanding of the chemical bond and the electronic  structure of molecules

name: Lord Patrick Maynard Stuart Blackett
motivation: developed an automatic Wilson cloud chamber; discovered electron-positron pair production in cosmic rays

name: Sir John Cockcroft
motivation: co-invented the first particle accelerator

name: Ir%26egrave;ne Joliot-Curie
motivation: co-discovered artificial radioactivity

name: Isador Isaac Rabi
motivation: developed the resonance technique for measuring the magnetic properties of atomic nuclei

name: Fr%26eacute;d%26eacute;ric Joliot-Curie
motivation: co-discovered artificial radioactivity

name: Dennis Gabor
motivation: invented and developed the holographic method whereby it is possible to record and display a three-dimensional display of an object

name: Wolfgang Pauli
motivation: discovered the exclusion principle; suggested the existence of the neutrino

name: Enrico Fermi
motivation: performed experiments leading to first self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction; developed a theory of beta decay that introduced the weak interaction; derived the statistical properties of gases that obey the Pauli exclusion principle

name: Werner Heisenberg
motivation: contributed to creation of quantum mechanics; introduced the ``uncertainty principle'' and the concept of exchange forces

name: Ernest Orlando Lawrence
motivation: invented the cyclotron

name: Paul Adrien Maurice Dirac
motivation: helped found quantum electrodynamics; predicted the existence of antimatter by combining quantum mechanics with special relativity

name: Alfred Kastler
motivation: discovered and developed optical methods for studying the Hertzian resonances that are produced when atoms interact with radio waves or microwaves

name: Eugene Wigner
motivation: contributed to theoretical atomic and nuclear physics; introduced concept of the nuclear cross section

name: Cecil F. Powell
motivation: developed the photographic emulsion method  of studying nuclear processes; discovered the charged pion

name: Ernest Walton
motivation: co-invented the first particle accelerator

name: Pavel A. Cherenkov
motivation: discovered the ``Cerenkov effect'' whereby light is emitted by a particle passing through a medium at a speed greater  than that of light in the medium

name: Carl David Anderson
motivation: discovered the positron and the muon

name: Felix Bloch
motivation: contributed to development of the NMR technique; measured the magnetic moment of the neutron; contributed to the theory of metals

name: Sir Nevill F. Mott
motivation: contributed to theoretical condensed-matter physics by applying quantum theory to complex phenomena in solids; calculated  cross section for relativistic Coulomb scattering

name: Emilio Segr%26egrave;
motivation: co-discovered the antiproton; discovered technetium

name: Hans Bethe
motivation: contributed to theoretical nuclear physics, especially concerning the mechanism for energy production in stars

name: Maria Goeppert-Mayer
motivation: advanced shell model of nuclear structure

name: Ernst Ruska
motivation: designed the first electron microscope

name: Shin-Ichiro Tomonaga
motivation: co-developed quantum electrodynamics

name: J. Hans D. Jensen
motivation: advanced shell model of nuclear structure

name: Edwin M. McMillan
motivation: made discoveries concerning the transuranium elements

name: Hideki Yukawa
motivation: predicted existence of the pion

name: John Bardeen
motivation: co-discovered the transistor effect; developed theory of superconductivity

name: Il'ja M. Frank
motivation: co-developed the theoretical interpretation of the radiation of electrons moving through matter faster than the speed of light (the ``Cerenkov effect''), and carried out experimental investigations of pair creation by gamma rays

name: Lev Landau
motivation: contributed to condensed matter theory on phenomena of superfluidity and superconductivity

name: Subramanyan Chandrasekhar
motivation: made important theoretical contributions concerning the structure and evolution of stars, especially white dwarfs

name: William Shockley
motivation: co-discovered the transistor effect

name: Luis Walter Alvarez
motivation: constructed huge bubble chambers and discovered many short-lived hadrons; advanced the impact theory for the extinction of the dinosaurs

name: William Fowler
motivation: studied nuclear reactions of astrophysical significance; developed, with others, a  theory of the formation of chemical elements in the universe

name: Polykarp Kusch
motivation: experimentally established that the  electron has an anomalous magnetic moment and made a precision determination of its magnitude

name: Edward Mills Purcell
motivation: developed method of nuclear resonance absorption that permitted the absolute determination of nuclear magnetic moments;  co-discovered a line in the galactic radiospectrum caused by atomic hydrogen

name: Glenn T. Seaborg
motivation: co-discovered plutonium and all further transuranium elements through element 102

name: Willis E. Lamb, Jr.
motivation: made discoveries concerning fine structure of hydrogen

name: Robert Hofstadter
motivation: measured charge distributions in atomic nuclei with high-energy electron scattering; measured the  charge and magnetic-moment distributions in the proton and neutron

name: Norman F. Ramsey, Jr.
motivation: developed the separated oscillatory fields method, which is the basis of the cesium atomic clock (our present time standard); co-invented the hydrogen maser

name: Clifford G. Shull
motivation: developed a neutron scattering technique in which a neutron diffraction pattern is produced that may be used to determine the atomic structure of a material

name: Charles H. Townes
motivation: created first maser using ammonia to produce coherent microwave radiation

name: Francis Crick
motivation: co-proposed the double-helix structure of DNA

name: Maurice Wilkins
motivation: investigated the structure of DNA

name: Bertram N. Brockhouse
motivation: developed the technique of neutron spectroscopy for studies of condensed matter

name: Richard P. Feynman
motivation: co-developed quantum electrodynamics; created a new formalism for practical calculations by introducing a graphical method called Feynman diagrams

name: Frederick Reines
motivation: established, together with Clyde L. Cowan, Jr., the existence of the electron antineutrino by detecting them using a reactor experiment

name: Julian Schwinger
motivation: co-developed quantum electrodynamics

name: Kai M. Siegbahn
motivation: contributed to the development of high-resolution electron spectroscopy

name: Nicolaas Bloembergen
motivation: contributed to the development of laser spectroscopy

name: Owen Chamberlain
motivation: co-discovered the antiproton

name: Yoichiro Nambu
motivation: contributed to elementary particle theory; recognized the role played by spontaneous symmetry-breaking in analogy with superconductivity theory; formulated QCD (quantum chromodynamics), the gauge theory of color

name: Andrei Sakharov
motivation: father of the Soviet hydrogen bomb; awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his struggle for human rights, for disarmament, and for  cooperation between all nations

name: Arthur L. Schawlow
motivation: contributed to the development of laser spectroscopy

name: Jack Steinberger
motivation: made many important discoveries in particle physics; co-discovered the neutral pion via photoproduction; co-discovered the muon neutrino

name: Nikolai Basov
motivation: worked in quantum electronics; independently worked out theoretical basis of the maser

name: Aage Bohr
motivation: contributed to theoretical understanding of collective motion in nuclei

name: Leon Lederman
motivation: contributed to the discovery of the muon neutrino and the bottom quark

name: Chen Ning Yang
motivation: co-proposed parity violation in weak interactions

name: Val Logsdon Fitch
motivation: co-discovered that decays of neutral kaons sometime violate CP conservation

name: Jack S. Kilby
motivation: invented the monolithic integrated circuit - the microchip - which laid the foundation for the field of microelectronics; co-invented the hand held calculator

name: Willard S. Boyle
motivation: co-invented the CCD (charge-coupled device)

name: Georges Charpak
motivation: invented the multiwire proportional chamber

name: Roy J. Glauber
motivation: made important contributions to the theoretical understanding of quantum optics and high-energy collisions

name: Simon van der Meer
motivation: contributed to experiments that led to the discovery of the carriers (W%26#177; and Z%26#176;) of the weak interaction

name: Donald A. Glaser
motivation: invented the bubble chamber

name: Henry W. Kendall
motivation: co-discovered, through investigations of deep-inelastic electron scattering, clear signs that there exists an inner structure (quarks and gluons) in the protons and neutrons of the atomic nucleus

name: Ben Mottelson
motivation: contributed to theoretical understanding of collective motion in nuclei

name: Tsung-Dao Lee
motivation: co-proposed parity violation in weak interactions

name: Abdus Salam
motivation: co-developed gauge field theory of the electroweak interaction; suggested that the proton might be unstable

name: K. Alexander M%26uuml;ller
motivation: co-discovered the first ceramic superconductors

name: Martin L. Perl
motivation: discovered the tau lepton

name: Murray Gell-Mann
motivation: advanced an explanation of strange particles; predicted the existence of the Omega- particle;  postulated existence of quarks; founded the study of QCD

name: Rudolf Ludwig M%26ouml;ssbauer
motivation: experimented with resonance absorption of gamma  radiation; discovered ``M%26ouml;ssbauer effect,'' the recoilless  emission of gamma rays by nuclei

name: Richard E. Taylor
motivation: co-discovered, through investigations of deep-inelastic electron scattering, clear signs that there exists an inner structure (quarks and gluons) in the protons and neutrons of the atomic nucleus

name: Leon N. Cooper
motivation: contributed to condensed matter theory on phenomena of superconductivity

name: Jerome I. Friedman
motivation: co-discovered, through investigations of deep-inelastic electron scattering, clear signs that there exists an inner structure (quarks and gluons) in the protons and neutrons of the atomic nucleus

name: George E. Smith
motivation: co-invented the CCD (charge-coupled device)

name: James W. Cronin
motivation: co-discovered that decays of neutral kaons sometime violate CP conservation

name: David M. Lee
motivation: co-discovered that the isotope Helium-3 becomes a quantum superfluid near absolute zero

name: Burton Richter
motivation: carried out an experiment leading to the discovery of charmonium

name: John Robert Schrieffer
motivation: contributed to condensed matter theory on phenomena of superconductivity

name: Pierre-Gilles de Gennes
motivation: developed theories in condensed matter physics applicable to liquid crystals and polymers

name: Sheldon Glashow
motivation: co-developed gauge field theory of the electroweak interaction

name: Melvin Schwartz
motivation: proposed that it should be possible to produce and use a beam of neutrinos; co-discovered the muon neutrino

name: Claude Cohen-Tannoudji
motivation: developed methods, with his colleagues, of using laser light to cool helium atoms to a temperature of about 0.18 %26#181;K and capturing the chilled atoms  in a trap

name: Charles K. Kao
motivation: pioneer in the development and use of fiber optics in telecommunications

name: Arno A. Penzias
motivation: co-discovered the cosmic microwave background radiation

name: Heinrich Rohrer
motivation: co-designed the scanning tunneling microscope (STM), a type of microscope in which a fine conducting probe is held close the surface of a sample

name: Steven Weinberg
motivation: co-developed gauge field theory of the electroweak interaction

name: Carlo Rubbia
motivation: contributed to experiments that led to the discovery of the carriers (W%26#177; and Z%26#176;) of the weak interaction

name: Robert W. Wilson
motivation: co-discovered the cosmic microwave background radiation

name: Samuel C. C. Ting
motivation: carried out an experiment leading to the discovery of charmonium

name: Kenneth Wilson
motivation: invented renormalization group methods  to develop a theory for critical phenomena in connection with phase transitions; contributed to solving QCD using lattice gauge theory

name: Robert C. Richardson
motivation: co-discovered that the isotope Helium-3 becomes a quantum superfluid near absolute zero

name: Albert Fert
motivation: co-discovered Giant Magnetoresistance, which brought about a breakthrough in gigabyte hard disks

name: Peter Gr%26uuml;nberg
motivation: co-discovered Giant Magnetoresistance, which brought about a breakthrough in gigabyte hard disks

name: Brian Josephson
motivation: contributed to theoretical predictions of the properties of a supercurrent through a tunnel barrier

name: Toshihide Maskawa
motivation: contributed to theoretical understanding of CP-violation; co-discovered the origin of the broken symmetry that predicts the existence of at least three families of quarks

name: David J. Gross
motivation: co-discovered ``asymptotic freedom'' in non-Abelian gauge theories; contributed to the development of string theory

name: Klaus von Klitzing
motivation: discovered the quantized Hall effect

name: Makato Kobayashi
motivation: contributed to theoretical understanding of CP-violation; co-discovered the origin of the broken symmetry that predicts the existence of at least three families of quarks

name: Douglas D. Osheroff
motivation: co-discovered that the isotope Helium-3 becomes a quantum superfluid near absolute zero

name: Gerard t' Hooft
motivation: contributed to theoretical understanding of gauge theories  in elementary particle physics, quantum gravity and black holes,  and fundamental aspects of quantum physics

name: Gerd Binnig
motivation: co-designed the scanning tunneling microscope (STM), a type of microscope in which a fine conducting probe is held close the surface of a sample

name: Steven Chu
motivation: developed the Doppler cooling method  of using laser light (optical molasses) to cool gases and capturing the chilled atoms in a magneto-optical trap (MOT)

name: William D. Phillips
motivation: developed, with his colleagues, a device called a Zeeman slower, with which he could  slow down and capture atoms in a purely magnetic trap

name: Hugh David Politzer
motivation: co-discovered ``asymptotic freedom'' in non-Abelian gauge theories; co-predicted the existence of charmonium - the bound state of a charm quark and its antiparticle

name: Johannes Georg Bednorz
motivation: co-discovered the first ceramic superconductors

name: Robert Laughlin
motivation: developed a theory of quantum fluids that explained the fractional quantum Hall effect

name: Frank Wilczek
motivation: co-discovered ``asymptotic freedom'' in non-Abelian gauge theories; contributed to the study of ``anyons''  (particle-like excitations in two-dimensional systems that obey ``fractional statistics'')

name: Andre Geim
motivation: co-discovered a simple method for isolating single atomic layers of graphite, known as graphene

name: Konstantin Novoselov
motivation: co-discovered a simple method for isolating single atomic layers of graphite, known as graphene

name: Wallace Clement Sabine
motivation: founded the science of architectural acoustics

name: Arnold Sommerfeld
motivation: generalized the circular orbits of the atomic Bohr model to elliptical orbits; introduced the magnetic quantum number; used statistical mechanics to explain the electronic properties of metals

name: Lise Meitner
motivation: co-discovered the element protactinium and studied the effects of neutron bombardment on uranium; introduced term ``fission'' for splitting the atomic nucleus

name: Paul Ehrenfest
motivation: applied quantum mechanics to rotating bodies; helped develop the modern statistical theory of nonequilibrium thermodynamics

name: Theodor von K%26aacute;rm%26aacute;n
motivation: provided major contributions to our understanding of fluid mechanics, turbulence theory, and supersonic flight

name: Walther Meissner
motivation: co-discovered the ``Meissner effect'',  whereby a superconductor expells a magnetic field

name: Emmy Noether
motivation: developed Noether's theorem, which relates the continuous symmetries of a physical system to specific conservation laws

name: Hans Geiger
motivation: helped measure charge-to-mass ratio for alpha particles; invented Geiger counter for detecting ionizing particles

name: Hermann Weyl
motivation: attempted to incorporate electromagnetism into general relativity; evolved the concept of continuous groups using matrix representations and applied group theory to quantum mechanics

name: Arthur Jeffrey Dempster
motivation: discovered the isotope uranium-235

name: Henry Moseley
motivation: developed the modern form of the period table of elements based on their atomic numbers

name: Sir Robert Watson-Watt
motivation: developed radar

name: Satyendra Bose
motivation: worked out statistical method of handling bosons (a group of particles named in his honor)

name: Oskar Klein
motivation: introduced the physical notion of extra dimensions that helped develop the Kaluza-Klein theory; co-developed the Klein-Gordon equation describing the relativistic behavior of spinless particles; co-developed the Klein-Nishina formula describing relativistic electron-photon scattering

name: Vladimir A. Fock
motivation: made fundamental contributions to quantum theory; invented the Hartree-Fock approximation method and the notion of Fock space

name: Leo Szilard
motivation: first suggested possibility of a nuclear chain reaction

name: Pierre Auger
motivation: discovered the Auger effect whereby an electron is ejected from an atom without the emission of an x-ray or gamma-ray photon as the result of the de-excitation of an excited electron within the atom; discovered cosmic-ray air showers

name: Ernst Ising
motivation: developed the Ising model of ferromagnetism

name: Fritz London
motivation: co-developed the phenomenological theory of  superconductivity; co-developed the first quantum-mechanical treatment of the hydrogen molecule; determined that the electromagnetic gauge is the phase of the Schr%26ouml;dinger wave function

name: Charles Francis Richter
motivation: established the Richter scale for the measurement of earthquake intensity

name: George E. Uhlenbeck
motivation: co-discovered that the electron has an intrinsic spin

name: Robert J. Van de Graaf
motivation: invented the Van de Graaf electrostatic generator

name: Samuel Abraham Goudsmit
motivation: co-discovered that the electron has an intrinsic spin

name: Igor Vasilievich Kurchatov
motivation: headed the Soviet atomic and hydrogen bomb programs

name: John von Neumann
motivation: formulated a fully quantum mechanical generalization  of statistical mechanics

name: George Gamow
motivation: first suggested hydrogen fusion as source of solar energy

name: J. Robert Oppenheimer
motivation: headed Manhattan Project to develop the nuclear fission bomb

name: Sir Rudolf Peierls
motivation: many contributions in theoretical physics, including an improved calculation of the critical mass needed to make a fission bomb

name: Edward Teller
motivation: helped develop atomic and hydrogen bombs

name: Victor F. Weisskopf
motivation: made theoretical contributions to quantum electrodynamics, nuclear structure, and elementary particle physics

name: Homi Jehangir Bhabha
motivation: initiated nuclear research programs in  India; carried out experiments in cosmic rays; calculated  cross section for elastic electron-positron scattering

name: Nikolai N. Bogolubov
motivation: theoretical physicist and mathematician who contributed to the microscopic theory of superfluidity; also contributed to theory of elementary particles, including the S-matrix and dispersion relations, and to nonlinear mechanics and the general theory of dynamical systems

name: Maurice Goldhaber
motivation: first measured (with James Chadwick) an accurate mass for the neutron; participated in experiments proving that beta rays are identical to atomic electrons; developed (with Edward Teller) the concept of coherent oscillations of protons and neutrons in nuclei leading to the giant dipole resonance; performed an experiment showing that neutrinos are created with negative helicity, which provided conclusive evidence for the V-A theory of weak interactions; participated in experiments that obtained an upper limit on the rate of proton decay and that provided evidence for neutrino oscillations

name: Chien-Shiung Wu
motivation: experimentally proved that parity is not conserved in nuclear beta decay

name: Henry Primakoff
motivation: co-developed the theory of spin waves; first described the process that became known as the ``Primakoff effect'' (the  coherent photoproduction of neutral mesons in the electric field of  an atomic nucleus); contributed to understanding of various manifestations of the weak interaction, including muon capture, double-beta decay, and the interaction of neutrinos with nuclei

name: Robert Rathbun Wilson
motivation: driving force behind creation of Fermilab and  Cornell University's  Laboratory of Nuclear Studies; a leader in the formation of the Federation of Atomic Scientists; did extensive measurements of kaon and pion photoproduction in which he made the first observation of a new state of the nucleon, N(1440)

name: Benoit Mandelbrot
motivation: developed theory of fractals
